In the divilion of the provinces, Augustus provided for his own power, and for the dignity of the republic. The proconsuls of the senate, particularly those of Asia, Creme, and Africa, enjoyed a more honourable character than the liente- nants of the emperor, who commanded in Gaul or Syria. The former were attended by lic'tors, the latter by soldiers. A law was passed, that wherever the emperor was present, his extraordinary commission should supersetle the ordinary jurisdiction of the governor, a custom was introduced, that the new conquests belonged to the Imperial portion, and it was soon discovered that the authority of the Princc, the favour-ite epithet of AugustuS, was the same in every part of the empire.

In return for this imaginary conceffion, Augustus obtained an important privilege, which rendered him master of Rome and Italy⁴ By a dangerous exception to the ancient maxims, he was authorized to preserve his military command, supported by a numerous body of guards, even in time of peace, and in the beart of the capital. His command indeed, was confined to those citi- zens who were engaged in the service by the military oath3 but such was the propensity of the Romans to servitude, that the oath was voluntarily taken by the magistrates, the senators, and the equestrian order, till the homage of flattery was insensibly converted into an annual and solemn protestation of fidelity. .

Although Augustus confidered a military force, as the firmest foundation, he vvisely rejectsd it, as a very odious instrument, of government.
